xxl.core.collections.queues.io

Class BlockBasedQueue

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.collections.queues.AbstractQueue<E>
      • xxl.core.collections.queues.io.StreamQueue
        • xxl.core.collections.queues.io.BlockBasedQueue
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, FIFOQueue, Queue, Convertable

    public class BlockBasedQueue
extends StreamQueue
implements Convertable, FIFOQueue
    This class provides a queue that uses a container for storing blocks of serialized data. The peek method is not implemented by the block based queue. A converter is used for serializing and de-serializing the elements of the queue.

    The block based queue serializes its elements and stores blocks of this serialized data in a container. In order to keep the order of this block, the id of the next block is stored at the end of each block.

    Example usage (1). 

         // create a new block based queue with ...

     BlockBasedQueue queue = new BlockBasedQueue(

         // a map container for storing the serialized elements

         new MapContainer(),

         // a block size of 20 bytes

         20,

         // an integer converter

         IntegerConverter.DEFAULT_INSTANCE,

         // an input buffer of 0 bytes

         new Constant(0),

         // an output buffer of 4 bytes (size of a serialized integer)

         new Constant(4)
     );

     // open the queue
 
     queue.open();

     // create an iteration over 20 random Integers (between 0 and 100)
     
     Iterator iterator = new Enumerator(20);

     // insert all elements of the given iterator

     for (; iterator.hasNext(); queue.enqueue(iterator.next()));

     // print all elements of the queue
     
     while (!queue.isEmpty())
          System.out.println(queue.dequeue());

     System.out.println();

     // close the open queue after use
     
     queue.close();
    See Also:
    Queue, StreamQueue, FIFOQueue, Container, Serialized Form

    • Field Detail

      • FACTORY_METHOD

        public static final Function<Object,BlockBasedQueue> FACTORY_METHOD
        A factory method to create a new BlockBasedQueue (see contract for FACTORY_METHOD in interface Queue). In contradiction to the contract in Queue it may only be invoked with a parameter list (for further details see Function) of objects. The parameter list will be used for initializing the random access file queue by calling the constructor 
                BlockBasedQueue((Container) list.get(0), 
                         256, 
                  (Function) list.get(1), 
                  new Constant(0), 
                  new Constant(0))
        See Also:
        Function

      • container

        protected Container container
        The container is internally used for storing the blocks that contains the serialized elements of the queue.

      • blockSize

        protected int blockSize
        The size of a block stored in the container. Every block stored in the container contains blockSize bytes of serialized data.

      • bytes

        protected int bytes
        The number of bytes stored by blocks in the container.

      • readBlockId

        protected Object readBlockId
        The id of readBlock, i.e. the block the queue currently reads from.

      • readBlockOffset

        protected int readBlockOffset
        The offset of readBlock, i.e. the block the queue currently reads from.

      • writeBlockId

        protected Object writeBlockId
        The id of writeBlock, i.e. the block the queue currently writes to.

      • writeBlockOffset

        protected int writeBlockOffset
        The offset of writeBlock, i.e. the block the queue currently writes to.

      • readBlock

        protected Block readBlock
        The block the queue currently reads from.

      • writeBlock

        protected Block writeBlock
        The block the queue currently writes to.

      • dummyBlock

        protected Block dummyBlock
        A dummy block that is used for getting a new id when a new write block is created. When creating a new write block, the dummy block is inserted into the container in order to get a valid id for the write block. When the creation of the write block is finished, the the dummy block is updated by the write block.

      • outputStream

        protected OutputStream outputStream
        The output stream is used for writing serialized elements to the queue. It is set to an output stream, that writes given bytes to the current write block. When the current write block is full, a new block is inserted into the container. In order to be able to determine the next block, when reading the serialized data, the id of the new block is stored at the end of the old write block. The output stream implicitly adjusts the number of bytes contained by the queue.

    • Constructor Detail

      • BlockBasedQueue

        public BlockBasedQueue(Container container,
                       int blockSize,
                       Converter converter,
                       Function newObject,
                       Function inputBufferSize,
                       Function outputBufferSize,
                       int size,
                       int bytes,
                       Object readBlockId,
                       int readBlockOffset,
                       Object writeBlockId,
                       int writeBlockOffset)
        Constructs a new block based queue containing the elements that are stored in blocks of the specified size in the given container. The specified converter is used for serializing and de-serializing the elements of the queue and the given factory method is used for initializing the elements of the queue before the blocks are read out. The specified functions determine the size of the input buffer and the output buffer. The given int value size and bytes determines what is the initial size of the queue and how many bytes are needed for serializing its elements. readBlockId, readBlockOffset, writeBlockId and writeBlockOffset specifies the id and the offset of the actual read and write block.
        Parameters:
        container - the container that is used for storing the blocks of serialized data. The serialized objects contained by this container can be used as initial elements of the queue.
        blockSize - the size of a block that is used for storing the serialized elements of the queue.
        converter - the converter that is used for serializing and de-serializing the elements of the queue.
        newObject - a factory method that is invoked in order to initialize the elements of the queue, before a block is read out.
        inputBufferSize - a function that determines the size of the input buffer.
        outputBufferSize - a function that determines the size of the output buffer.
        size - the initial size of the queue.
        bytes - the number of bytes needed for storing the initial elements of the queue.
        readBlockId - the id of the actual block to read from.
        readBlockOffset - the offset of the actual block to read from.
        writeBlockId - the id of the actual block to write to.
        writeBlockOffset - the offset of the actual block to write to.

      • BlockBasedQueue

        public BlockBasedQueue(Container container,
                       int blockSize,
                       Converter converter,
                       Function inputBufferSize,
                       Function outputBufferSize,
                       int size,
                       int bytes,
                       Object readBlockId,
                       int readBlockOffset,
                       Object writeBlockId,
                       int writeBlockOffset)
        Constructs a new block based queue containing the elements that are stored in blocks of the specified size in the given container. The specified converter is used for serializing and de-serializing the elements of the queue. The specified functions determine the size of the input buffer and the output buffer. The given int value size and bytes determines what is the initial size of the queue and how many bytes are needed for serializing its elements. readBlockId, readBlockOffset, writeBlockId and writeBlockOffset specifies the id and the offset of the actual read and write block.
        This constructor is equivalent to the call of BlockBasedQueue(container, blockSize, converter, new Constant(null), inputBufferSize, outputBufferSize, size, bytes, readBlockId, readBlockOffset, writeBlockId, writeBlockOffset)
        Parameters:
        container - the container that is used for storing the blocks of serialized data. The serialized objects contained by this container can be used as initial elements of the queue.
        blockSize - the size of a block that is used for storing the serialized elements of the queue.
        converter - the converter that is used for serializing and de-serializing the elements of the queue.
        inputBufferSize - a function that determines the size of the input buffer.
        outputBufferSize - a function that determines the size of the output buffer.
        size - the initial size of the queue.
        bytes - the number of bytes needed for storing the initial elements of the queue.
        readBlockId - the id of the actual block to read from.
        readBlockOffset - the offset of the actual block to read from.
        writeBlockId - the id of the actual block to write to.
        writeBlockOffset - the offset of the actual block to write to.

        public BlockBasedQueue(Container container,
                       int blockSize,

                       Function outputBufferSize,

                       Object readBlockId,

                       Object writeBlockId,
                       int writeBlockOffset)
        Constructs a new block based queue containing the elements that are stored in blocks of the specified size in the given container. A convertable converter is used for serializing and de-serializing the elements of the queue and the given factory method is used for initializing the elements of the queue before the blocks are read out. The specified functions determine the size of the input buffer and the output buffer. The given int value size and bytes determines what is the initial size of the queue and how many bytes are needed for serializing its elements. readBlockId, readBlockOffset, writeBlockId and writeBlockOffset specifies the id and the offset of the actual read and write block.
        This constructor is equivalent to the call of BlockBasedQueue(container, blockSize, ConvertableConverter.DEFAULT_INSTANCE, new Constant(null), inputBufferSize, outputBufferSize, size, bytes, readBlockId, readBlockOffset, writeBlockId, writeBlockOffset)
        Parameters:
        container - the container that is used for storing the blocks of serialized data. The serialized objects contained by this container can be used as initial elements of the queue.
        blockSize - the size of a block that is used for storing the serialized elements of the queue.
        newObject - a factory method that is invoked in order to initialize the elements of the queue, before a block is read out.
        inputBufferSize - a function that determines the size of the input buffer.
        outputBufferSize - a function that determines the size of the output buffer.
        size - the initial size of the queue.
        bytes - the number of bytes needed for storing the initial elements of the queue.
        readBlockId - the id of the actual block to read from.
        readBlockOffset - the offset of the actual block to read from.
        writeBlockId - the id of the actual block to write to.
        writeBlockOffset - the offset of the actual block to write to.

        public BlockBasedQueue(Container container,
                       int blockSize,
                       Converter converter,
                       Function newObject,
                       Function inputBufferSize,
                       Function outputBufferSize)
        Constructs a new block based queue containing the elements that are stored in blocks of the specified size in the given container (see methods read and write for further detail). The specified converter is used for serializing and de-serializing the elements of the queue and the given factory method is used for initializing the elements of the queue before the blocks are read out. The specified functions determine the size of the input buffer and the output buffer.
        This constructor is equivalent to the call of BlockBasedQueue(container, blockSize, converter, newObject, inputBufferSize, outputBufferSize, 0, 0, null, ShortConverter.SIZE, null, ShortConverter.SIZE).
        Parameters:
        container - the container that is used for storing the blocks of serialized data. The serialized objects contained by this container can be used as initial elements of the queue.
        blockSize - the size of a block that is used for storing the serialized elements of the queue.
        converter - the converter that is used for serializing and de-serializing the elements of the queue.
        newObject - a factory method that is invoked in order to initialize the elements of the queue, before a block is read out.
        inputBufferSize - a function that determines the size of the input buffer.
        outputBufferSize - a function that determines the size of the output buffer.

        public BlockBasedQueue(Container container,
                       int blockSize,
                       Function newObject,
                       Function inputBufferSize,
                       Function outputBufferSize)
        Constructs a new block based queue containing the elements that are stored in blocks of the specified size in the given container (see methods read and write for further detail). A Convertable converter is used for serializing and de-serializing the elements of the queue and the given factory method is used for initializing the elements of the queue before the blocks are read out. The specified functions determine the size of the input buffer and the output buffer.
        This constructor is equivalent to the call of BlockBasedQueue(container, blockSize, ConvertableConverter.DEFAULT_INSTANCE, newObject, inputBufferSize, outputBufferSize).

        newObject - a factory method that is invoked in order to initialize the elements of the queue, before a block is read out.

      • createBlockBasedQueueFunctionForMergeSorter

        public static <T> Function<Function<?,Integer>,Queue<T>> createBlockBasedQueueFunctionForMergeSorter(Container queueContainer,
                                                                                                     int blockSize,
                                                                                                     Converter<T> converter)
        This function can be used for initialization of external sorting. This constructor has a parameter function, which is a factory function for storing intermediate runs. MergeSorter.MergeSorter(java.util.Iterator, java.util.Comparator, int, int, int, Function, boolean) MergeSorter
        Parameters:
        queueContainer - container e.g. BlockFileContainer
        blockSize - in bytes e.g. 4096
        converter - for data serializing
        Returns:

      • read

        public void read(DataInput dataInput)
          throws IOException
        Reads the state of this block based queue from a data input. This method can be used for initializing the queue with the elements that are stored in blocks of bytes in the container without using the corresponding constructor (you know, the one with twelve parameters).
        This implementation reads the fields size, bytes, readBlockId, readBlockOffset, writeBlockId and writeBlockOffset from the given data input.
        Specified by:
        read in interface Convertable
        Parameters:
        dataInput - the data input to read from the state of this queue.
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs.

      • write

        public void write(DataOutput dataOutput)
           throws IOException
        Writes the actual state of this block based queue to a data output. This method can be used for serializing the actual state of the queue in order to use it again in another session without calling the corresponding constructor (you know, the one with twelve parameters).
        This implementation writes the fields size, bytes, readBlockId, readBlockOffset, writeBlockId and writeBlockOffset to the given data output.
        Specified by:
        write in interface Convertable
        Parameters:
        dataOutput - the data output to write to the state of this queue.
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs.

        public int bytes()
        Returns the number of bytes needed for serializing the elements of this queue.
        Returns:
        the number of bytes stored by blocks in the container.

        public Object readBlockId()

        the id stored in readBlockId.

        public int writeBlockOffset()
        Returns the offset of the actual block to write to.
        Returns:
        the offset stored in writeBlockOffset.

      • removeBlock

        protected void removeBlock()
                    throws IOException
        Removes the actual block to read from out of the container and sets readBlockId to the id of the next block to read from. The id of the next block is stored at the end of the removed block.
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs.

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Removes all elements from this queue. The queue will be empty after this call returns so that size() == 0.
        This implementation removes all blocks from the container and sets size and bytes to 0. Thereafter the actual blocks are set to null.
        Specified by:
        clear in interface Queue
        Overrides:
        clear in class StreamQueue

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes this queue and releases any system resources associated with it. This operation is idempotent, i.e., multiple calls of this method takes the same effect as a single call.
        This implementation secures that the actual state of the block to write to is stored in the container and sets the actual blocks to null.
        Specified by:
        close in interface Queue
        Overrides:
        close in class StreamQueue
